title: 103_s2476
content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Spousal IRA Computed on Basis of Compensation of Both Spouses" amendment in the "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows for a special rule where the IRA contribution limit is based on the combined compensation of both spouses. The amendment allows for a special rule where the IRA contribution limit is based on the combined compensation of both spouses. It applies to individuals filing a joint return with one spouse having less compensation than the other. Amendments to other sections and the effective date are also specified. Individuals can use distributions from certain plans without penalty to purchase first homes, pay for higher education or qualified long-term care expenses, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from individual retirement plans or employer contributions can be used for first-time homebuyer expenses, higher education, or long-term care without penalty. Definitions for these distributions are provided in the amendments to section 72(t). The amendments to section 72(t) define qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments used within 60 days for acquiring a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. Qualified acquisition costs include expenses for acquiring, constructing, or improving the residence. The term 'qualified acquisition costs' refers to the expenses of acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement and closing costs. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who has not owned a principal residence in the past three years before acquiring the new residence. The term 'qualified acquisition costs' include expenses for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, such as settlement and closing costs. A first-time homebuyer is someone who has not owned a principal residence in the three years before acquiring a new residence. Subsection (a)(6), (h), or (k) of section 1034 does not suspend the running of any time period specified in section 1034 for an individual before the distribution is applied. The term 'principal residence' and 'date of acquisition' have the same meanings as in section 1034. If a distribution from an individual retirement plan fails to meet requirements for acquiring or constructing a principal residence due to delay, the amount can be contributed back to the plan within 120 days. Certain rules do not apply to this contribution, and the amount is not considered for other contributions. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution. These expenses can be for the taxpayer, their spouse, child, or grandchild. The amount is reduced by any income excludable under section 135. Qualified long-term care expenses are amounts paid for necessary services required by functionally impaired individuals, including diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services. This includes insurance covering such services. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a functionally impaired individual and the criteria for services provided to them under a continuing plan of care. This is in the context of qualified long-term care expenses for necessary services required by functionally impaired individuals. The definition of a functionally impaired individual is someone unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. This includes verbal reminding, physical cueing, or supervision. Special rules apply for home health care services provided to such individuals. Activities of daily living include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. A licensed health care practitioner refers to a physician or registered professional. A licensed health care practitioner is defined as a physician, registered professional nurse, or a qualified community care case manager. The latter must have experience or training in providing case management services and preparing individual care plans. A qualified community care case manager must have experience in assessing functional and cognitive impairment, not be a relative of the individual receiving services, and meet requirements set by the Secretary. The term 'relative' is defined as per section 152(a). Penalty-free distributions are available for certain unemployed individuals. Penalty-free distributions from individual retirement plans are allowed for unemployed individuals who have received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks. This provision is part of a series of amendments to various sections related to retirement plans. Amendments are made to sections 401(k)(2)(B)(i) and 403(b)(11) allowing penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses from individual retirement plans. Amendments allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses from individual retirement plans. Effective date applies to payments and distributions after the enactment of this Act.
